newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's DB-Soft calls AGM after losing capital.
newsitem.headline: Germany's DB-Soft calls AGM after losing capital.

text.p: German software group DB-Soft AG said on Monday that it lost half of its capital, forcing it to call a meeting of shareholders, and that its management board had resigned.

DB-Soft, a largely privately-held software maker, said the three months to the end of September, the first quarter of its business year, was unsatisfactory after the company made a loss in the 1995/96 business year to the end of June.
Gabriele Kiehl and Sabine Fraenzl, who made up the two-member management board, would resign effective immediately, the company said in a statement.
The supervisory board would undertake immediate action to improve the earnings potential of the company and appoint Burkhard Stiller, previously head of product development, to the management board.
DB-Soft has two large shareholders, Andreas Winkler and Karsten Fillmer, each of whom hold stakes of 37.5 percent. The remaining 25 percent of the company is widely held.

The company's shares are traded on the Munich stock exchange. Trade was suspended in the shares on Tuesday. They closed at 55 marks ($36.05) on Monday, off a year-low of 50 marks and down from a year-high of 134 marks.
